abstracts.cdata!:
The Coastal Contamination Prevention and
            Marine Management Project in Argentina, aims at reducing
            pollution in the Patagonia marine environment, and improve
            sustainable management of the marine biodiversity. The three
            main components will: 1) improve preparedness, and
            responsiveness to maritime pollution, and oil spills, and,
            prevent ship-based pollution, through: a) improved analysis
            of contingency plans, using modern technology for database
            organization; b) extensive training in oil spill mitigation,
            and, in oil spill trajectory modeling; and, c) improved
            enforcement of the International Convention for the
            Prevention of Pollution from Ships regulations. Navigational
            risks will be reduced by introducing a marine electronic
            infrastructure program, through an enhanced vessel tracking
            system, and implementation of hydrographic mapping of
            critical zones; 2) improve knowledge base, and identify
            ecologically sensitive areas of marine biodiversity, by
            targeting programs to understand the dynamics of ocean
            production, and environmental degradation of the Patagonian
            ecosystem, including trans-boundary analysis to complete
            ecological identification, and inter-calibration of key
            marine laboratories. Marine protection tools will be
            developed, through analyses of regulatory, and technical
            aspects to pilot marine reserves, and, an action program
            will be developed based on the evaluation of incidental
            catch of birds, or mammals; and, 3) support capacity
            building, and dissemination practices on marine biodiversity
            protection, including monitoring and evaluation, and project management.
